hints.content: The parentheses tell us which two numbers to multiply first.

Mayra solved the equation by multiplying $(\redE{6}\times\purpleE{2})$ first, and then multiplying by $\maroonE{4}$.

$\begin{align}
\redE{6} \times \purpleE{2} \times \maroonE{4} &=(\redE{6}\times\purpleE{2}) \times\maroonE{4}\\\\
&=\blueE{12}\times\maroonE{4}\\\\
&=48
\end{align}$

In the new equation below, we want to multiply $(\purpleE{2}\times\maroonE{4})$ first, and then multiply by $\redE{6}$.

$\begin{align}
\redE{6} \times \purpleE{2} \times \maroonE{4} &= \redE{6}\times(\purpleE{2}\times\maroonE{4})\\\\
&=\redE{6}\times\goldE{8}\\\\ 
&=48
\end{align}$

question.content:
Mayra solved $\redE{6} \times \purpleE{2} \times\maroonE{4}$ using the equations below.

$\begin{align}
\redE{6} \times \purpleE{2} \times \maroonE{4} &=(\redE{6}\times\purpleE{2}) \times\maroonE{4}\\\\ 
&=12 \times\maroonE{4}\\\\\  
&=48
\end{align}$

**Use the equations below to solve $\redE{6} \times \purpleE{2} \times \maroonE{4}$ in a different way.**

||
-:|:-
$\redE{6} \times \purpleE{2} \times \maroonE{4}$ | $=\redE{6}\times($ [[☃ numeric-input 1]]${}\times\maroonE{4})$  |
|$= \redE{6}\times {}$  [[☃ numeric-input 2]]|
|$= 48$|
